content.webTitle: Women’s State of Origin soars to unimaginable heights in 12 months | Larissa O'Connor

fields.headline: Women’s State of Origin soars to unimaginable heights in 12 months
fields.bodyText: Australia has hit one of its biggest ever weekends of women’s sport, and proceedings got underway on Friday night when more than 10,500 people of all ages, all genders and all orientations crammed into the historic North Sydney Oval to witness the second edition of Women’s State of Origin. By kick-off, the mercury had dropped to 11 degrees, yet a queue of people awaiting admission stretched nearly 100m down Miller Street. In 12 months, this game has soared to unimaginable heights and those in attendance were lending their unconditional support. Fourteen-year-old Jackson Terry of North Sydney said he was drawn to the game through increased publicity and a love of the Blues (note there is no asterisk on Blues, no definition of men or women, just Blues). “Their skills are admirable and nothing short of outstanding,” Jackson said as the players completed their pre-game warm-up. The Year 9 student and Under-15s rugby league junior attends women’s sport on a semi-regular basis, especially women’s cricket played on the same oval. “Women’s sport is heading in the right direction really quickly. It is terrific especially with [tennis player] Ash Barty leading the way and the Matildas doing so well in the World Cup.” The Matildas – one of Australia’s most successful teams at present – have overcome early tournament jitters to find themselves among the last 16 teams at the Fifa World Cup, earning the right to play Norway on Sunday morning. Comeback queen Barty won the French Open earlier this month and has taken the same form into the Birmingham Classic. The 24-year-old defeated Venus Williams on Saturday morning to move into the semi-finals and one step closer to a tournament win which will see her top the world rankings; a position no Australian woman has held for over 40 years. But on Friday all eyes were on Women’s Origin – plenty of them, given it was broadcast on prime-time television and an audience of a million-plus tuned in. Former footballer and softball player, Jasmin Kitching, said she was “blown away” by her first experience of women’s elite rugby league. “I didn’t know if it would be televised and thought if it was, it would be on SBS or played late,” Kitching said. “But when I found out it was live on Channel 9, I thought this is so good. With women, it has been hard with everything, let alone sport, so this is massive.” The interstate clash brought together a solid list of league administrators and senior politicians who were treated as virtual celebrities in an emphatic crowd. Among them was Stuart Clark, the former Australian cricketer and NSW Rugby League’s chief operating officer. “It’s been wonderful for everyone from the pre-game to the game, to two to three thousand people mobbing the girls after the game,” Stuart said as thousands burst on to the oval at full-time to meet their Origin heroines. “It’s certainly here to stay. While everyone says [women’s league] is a growth area, it is also about equality; about giving these girls an opportunity that in the past, they wouldn’t have got.” Completely swamped somewhere in the centre of the on-field celebrations was diminutive NSW halfback Maddie Studdon. Having been awarded the Nellie Doherty medal for best-on-field just moments earlier, her grandfather, John Hurst proudly looked on as his granddaughter signed endless autographs and was photographed with her adoring fans. Hurst, a former South Sydney Rabbitohs trainer, finds himself in an era he could have never dreamed of. “I think whoever organised the women’s game, people such as Katie Page [CEO of Harvey Norman, a major sponsor of women’s league] should be congratulated,” he said. “Tonight was a great spectacle, the crowd was enormous. Hopefully along the track we might not get just one State of Origin game for the women, but a series like the men.” In days gone by, sceptics of women’s sport were fixated on an imbalance of physical strength but over time, many are recognising this genre’s aura of excitement, wholesomeness and determination which resonate widely. It’s a recipe which has seen audiences grow in key sectors such as netball, AFL and more recently, league. It’s now not a case of whether the women should play a curtain raiser during the year, but where next year’s Origin will be held seeing North Sydney Oval could barely hold last night’s crowd and once again, food supplies were exhausted in the first half. “It is a really big thing for both teams to sell out a crowd, this game is going huge places,” said the Maroons captain, Ali Brigginshaw, after the 14-4 loss to NSW. “I had half of the women’s rugby 7s message me before the game to say good luck. We are all supporting each other to get through hurdles and stand on top of the stage.”
